transcript:
Meet Eric and Tami. They&#39;ve been friends since they were children
and have recently found out that they share a challenging health diagnosis. They both have diabetes. Diabetes is a disease that occurs when the
amount of glucose or blood sugar in the body gets too high. It can be dangerous if untreated because high
blood sugar impacts our ability to function daily and can lead to serious health problems
such as heart disease, vision loss, amputations, kidney disease, and even death, if not properly
managed. It&#39;s important to know that there are two
kinds of diabetes. Eric, who is now 46 years old, discovered
that he had type one diabetes when he was in elementary school. He complained to his parents about increased
thirst, blurry vision, fatigue, and weakness. The doctor soon diagnosed him with type one
diabetes, which is usually found in children, teens, and young adults. It meant that his body can&#39;t make its own
insulin or makes very little insulin, insulin, a hormone made by the pancreas, helps glucose
get from our food to ourselves to be used for energy. Although no one knows how to prevent type
one diabetes, we do know that it can run in families. And there are about one and a half million
people in the United States with the condition. There is no cure for type one diabetes, but
it can be managed. Eric manages his type one diabetes by taking
daily insulin shots, eating a healthy diet, exercising on a regular basis, and by visiting
his medical provider regularly for checkups. Tammy has type two diabetes, the more common
kind of the disease, currently, more than 30 million Americans have this form of diabetes,
which means that the body still produces insulin, but it&#39;s unable to use it, effectively raising
the body&#39;s blood sugar level. Tammy was diagnosed with the disease as an
adult when she was 45 years old. Some of Tammy&#39;s risk factors were being overweight
and being a smoker. She is also African-American, and unfortunately,
type two diabetes has a disproportionate impact on some racial and ethnic groups. Unlike Eric, Tammy didn&#39;t experience any immediate
symptoms. It wasn&#39;t until she had a routine checkup
with her doctor when she was diagnosed. This is common for people who have type two
diabetes. Some people do not find out they have the
disease until they have had a diabetes-related health problem, such as blurred vision, increased
thirst or unexplained weight loss. But unlike type one diabetes, some people
living with type two diabetes can manage their condition with a healthy diet and exercise
alone. But in some cases, people may need medications
or insulin to keep their diabetes under control. Tammy needed a little more support outside
of diet and exercise, so her doctor prescribed medications that help her body manage the
disease. Eric and Tami understand that both forms of
the disease can be managed. They check their blood glucose level every
day to determine whether that level is within their target ranges. They take their prescribed diabetes medicines. They both also make sure to keep their blood
pressure and cholesterol under control. To learn more about diabetes, visit our website
www.fda.gov/healthequity.

10 signs that you have diabetes from endocrinologists number one always hungry number two blurry fishing number three numbness and tingling in limbs number four frequent urination number five always thirsty number six hyperpigmentation and dark patches and skin tacks number seven belly fat and increased waistline number eight swollen feet or legs number nine dry crack skin and 10 low energy and fatigue

China has achieved a significant medical Milestone they have successfully cured a diabetes patient how so using a pionering cell therapy after only 3 months of treatment the patient was no longer dependent on insulin injections our next report telling you more they just might be hope for those suffering from diabetes in a significant medical milestone Chinese scientists have successfully cured a patient&#39;s diabetes how did they achieve this feat using a groundbreaking Cell Therapy a team from Shanghai Chang xang Hospital the center for excellence in molecular cell science and renji Hospital have developed this treatment all the details have been detailed in the journal cell Discovery the patient underwent the cell transplant in July 2021 within 11 weeks he no longer required external insulin if you or someone you know has diabetes you could understand how tedious these insulin shorts can be fortunately the patient did not need them anymore over the next one year he gradually reduced taking oral medication for blood sugar control reaching a point when he didn&#39;t need them at all followup examinations showed that the patients pancreatic functions were effectively restored how did thaten happen the new therapy involved programming the patients blood cells it transformed them into seed cells to recreate pancreatic eyelet tissue in an artificial environment let me break that down for you a body needs insulin to maintain blood glucose levels the pancreatic eyelet tissue contain beta cells that release insulin in diabetes these cells stop working so body stops producing its own insulin it becomes dependent on external factors for that that&#39;s why patients need insulin injections and constant monitoring however the new cell therapy can transform some of the patient blood cells into seed cells these cells can function as the beta cells of the pancreatic eyelet tissue and release insulin therefore a diabetes patient doesn&#39;t need to depend on external insulin anymore this approach leverages the body&#39;s regenerative capabilities it&#39;s an emerging field known as regenerative Medicine China can significantly benefit from the new treatment after all it has the highest number of diabetes patients globally 140 million people in China have diabetes 40 million rely on lifelong insulin injections this new cell therapy could significantly reduce this burden Bureau report weon world this one to stay up to speed with the latest news download the weon app And subscribe to our YouTube channel

DR. MANGIONE: Geriatricians face a lot of challenges when providing diabetes care, and the challenges really stem from the fact that most older
adults don&#39;t just have diabetes. They&#39;re likely to have hypertension, many
of them may have chronic renal disease, but they also may have things that aren&#39;t directly
related to their diabetes, such as osteoarthritis, chronic pain from other problems. I think the biggest challenges are really
about setting priorities and making sure that you keep things as simple as you can, but
at the same time, making sure that you&#39;re offering the therapies that reduce morbidity
and lengthen life and improve quality of life for patients. Another big challenge with caring for older
adults with diabetes is that it is a very heterogeneous population. Now when you think about it, if somebody is
68 or 69, they could be a person who&#39;s had type 2 diabetes for 30 years, and it could
be well controlled. But you can also have somebody at the same
age who may have already had a stroke, who may have found out a year ago that they have
type 2 diabetes. So, we can&#39;t just go with age. We have to really think about life expectancy. We have to think about what are the other
chronic conditions that the person has under treatment. We also have to think about their functional
status, and we have to think a lot about their cognitive status and family support. We know that older adults with type 2 diabetes
are much more likely to get a group of conditions that we call the geriatric syndromes than
people who are of a similar age and don&#39;t have diabetes. These geriatric syndromes include gait problems
and falls, cognitive impairment, higher rates of depression, higher rates of chronic pain,
urinary continence, and challenges with what we call polypharmacy. Medicare beneficiaries, oftentimes people
over 65, will be on six or more prescription drugs. And when you think about how hard it is to
just take one antibiotic correctly when you get sick, you can imagine what it must be
like to try to take all of these pills correctly every day. The probability of drug-drug interactions,
creating yet a third symptom, happens quite frequently. And as medical regimens get more complex and
more medications are added, adherence goes down. So, in addition to taking care of the diabetes,
these conditions really need to be screened for because many of them are treatable. And I have to mention that particularly depression
travels a lot with diabetes, and we have a growing evidence base that, if you don&#39;t treat
the depression, it&#39;s very hard, not only for older adults but for all adults, to take care
of their diabetes. You really have to take a very holistic approach
to the person you&#39;re treating and, as much as possible, you need to engage them in shared
decision-making. So, with patients with type 2 diabetes who
are older, the frail ones and the people with impaired cognition, there are a lot of family
meetings in these decision-making sessions. And we really, as a group, have to decide
what&#39;s going to be the most feasible and practical care plan to keep someone&#39;s quality of life
as high as possible, for as long as possible, and to keep the burden of our treatments as
low as possible. The Guiding Principles have a lot of very
useful information for taking care of older adults. And the document that came out of this process
has 10 guiding principles. They&#39;re very practical. And for all of us who care for older adults
with type 2 diabetes, it provides a very efficient place to find that information. So, I would encourage you to look at it and
incorporate some of the suggestions into your practice. I think you&#39;ll find it helpful.

necrobiosis lepoidica and it&#39;s an uncommon inflammatory condition usually starts as one or more small red raised patches on both shins you may also get other patches on other parts of the body like your hands or your trunk these lesions grow slowly and may sometimes join up to form larger flatter irregular shaped patches usually with well-defined red borders they may also have a bit of like a yellowish Center and visible blood vessels as well condition is most commonly seen in people with diabetes both type 1 and also type 2. we don&#39;t really know the cause but some theories suggest that it could be damaged to areas that give the skin its strength so these are your collagen fibers okay on to number two these dark skin patches are called acanthosis negricans and usually they appear on your neck armpits groin anywhere where you might have skin folds the reason why it happens isn&#39;t usually clear but it&#39;s thought to be linked with insulin resistance which is one of the key mechanisms behind why people get diabetes this is also why it may occur in people who are overweight obese but also people who have other metabolic conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome and Cushing syndrome these tiny red bumps can occur around your ankles around your hands your arms and Accord granuloma annular the rash is not normally painful but it can be slightly itchy it&#39;s not contagious and usually gets better on its own within a few months it is thought that the process behind why it appears as likely due to inflammation and it can be linked to a few conditions including diabetes autoimmune thyroiditis high cholesterol called hyperlipidemia and some very very rare forms of cancer the medical name for this condition is xanthalasma this happens when your body collects extra cholesterol and deposits it around the eyes so you might notice flat or slightly raised yellow growths on or around the eyelids these deposits are usually harmless but could signal uncontrolled diabetes or high cholesterol okay so if you develop a breakout a small reddish yellow bumps across your body this can be a sign of underlying metabolic disease and one of the main causes of this eruption is uncontrolled diabetes the medical name for it is eruptive xanthomatosis so what does it look like well it&#39;s a breakout of these small pimply waxy bumps that can appear on your hands feet arms legs pretty much anywhere including your bottom the eruptions themselves are usually not painful but in some cases can cause a little bit of an itch the good news is again with most of these things it&#39;s not contagious so you can&#39;t pass on from one person to another this condition causes limited joint movement in the hand and its medical name is diabetic chiroarthropathy it&#39;s quite a mouthful or you can just simply call it diabetic hand syndrome it&#39;s characterized by waxy skin that&#39;s thickened over the Palm aspect of your hand which reduces the mobility of your hand opening up especially across the mCP joints and your pip joints if you want to test yourself to see if you have this condition the simple test that we do in clinics is a prayer sign you basically bring the palm of your hands together like so normally you should be able to bring your hands together and have like full contact if however you have this kind of appearance of your hand and you&#39;re not able to make like full contact with the palm of your hand on both sides then you&#39;ve probably got this condition so if you&#39;ve got this kind of bending of your hand and alternative test for this is something called the tabletop sign in which you basically will Pretend This is a table you place your hand on a table and it should all be kind of flat however if you notice that your hand is slightly kind of raised or hasn&#39;t got full contact with the table again that&#39;s a positive sign this is a book let&#39;s call it the book Sign it&#39;s always exclusive to diabetes you can get it with connective tissue conditions like Scleroderma but also other conditions like dupatron&#39;s contracture and Palmar fasciitis as well now these sores can start with nothing more than a small bump or scrape and if you have diabetes then you are at higher risk of developing ulcers this is why diabetics have yearly foot and leg checks which assesses the leg for sensation and the development of sores and ulcers so why are diabetics more at risk of developing these well there are quite a few different factors on this one the very first one is the diabetics are more at risk of developing something called diabetic neuropathy what does that mean well basically it&#39;s damage to your nerves imagine you&#39;re touching something hot on the hob immediate reaction your body would have is to pull your hand away and that&#39;s your nervous system working with your nervous system isn&#39;t working properly like some people who have diabetes those little pains and pressure points don&#39;t cause the same reactions so your typical pains and pressure points don&#39;t really get registered by the brain so some areas where you&#39;ve got a sore or a bump or a break in the skin will get bigger because you don&#39;t have your natural body response diabetics can also have poor circulation and high sugar levels which can slow down the healing process and make them more prone to infections and obviously getting a wound infection is never good it can also delay the amount of time it takes people for it to heal and will come on to infections in a moment but first these are called skin tags they are super common lots of people have them it doesn&#39;t mean you have diabetes if you have them but what we know is that if you are diabetes you tend to have more skin tags but what we tend to see is that sometimes you can get them as a result of diabetes the reason why people get it isn&#39;t really clear but I think it&#39;s a number of different factors including insulin resistance obesity or being overweight and also hormonal changes in the body it&#39;s important to mention that most people with skin tags will not have diabetes and there also may be genetic reasons why some people get more skin tags than other people this is a common skin condition that affects people with diabetes these small round or oval shaped patches can typically appear on your lower legs especially on The Shins and they can be light brown or reddish in color and are slightly indented sometimes they have a slightly shiny surface to it too and again as you may have guessed we don&#39;t fully know why diabetics develop it but diabetic dermopathy is thought to be related to damage to the small vessels around that Supply the skin and so poor circulation that changes the structure of your skin may also contribute to the development of these patches number 10 is a common complaint even among people who don&#39;t have diabetes but itchy skin can result from dry skin or poor circulation both of which are more likely when you are diabetic on to the next one when you&#39;ve got diabetes you have high sugar levels and this can encourage the growth of fungal infections fungi love to hang out in moist folds as we&#39;ve talked about before and that includes your armpits your groin under your breasts around your nails but also in your mouth as well as we&#39;ve mentioned before with high sugar levels our immune system doesn&#39;t really work as well as it should do so people often get recurrent infections so if you&#39;re getting lots of thrush infections either in your tongues or genitals or if you&#39;re getting fungal infections on your skin or feet then it should be really important to see a doctor to make sure you&#39;re tested to diabetes the treatment often is very simple with anti-fungal creams and it should subside after a few weeks now similar to fungal infections bacterial infections are also more common in diabetics this raises your risk of skin infections with staphylococcus being the most common one you may also get other types of of infections like cellulitis which is redness of the skin it can also be hot to touch untreated it can track up and spread around the body making you feel unwell makes you have high temperatures and again it&#39;s important that if you&#39;re getting recurrent bacterial infections like impetigo like cellulitis like folliculitis then it&#39;s important to rule out diabetes and finally diabetics are also more prone to developing skin blisters these might pop up Suddenly on your fingers toes hands feet sometimes your legs they can develop there due to friction or if you&#39;ve got neuropathy you may not have felt the irritation on your skin other times and more rarely it can be a rare sign of long-standing diabetes if you&#39;re getting multiple blisters forming all over the body then it&#39;s important to see a doctor and get it investigated okay there you have it that&#39;s been your 13 skin size that are linked with diabetes but again the super important caveat to all of this is if you have one of these it&#39;s not a certainty that it&#39;s diabetes some can occur on their own some can be genetic and you could be absolutely fine some can be actually linked with other conditions but it&#39;s important that if you&#39;re getting a few of these or you&#39;re concerned you might have diabetes most important thing is to get tested if you want me to go through the most common signs and symptoms of diabetes then click here to see if you have any of them once [Music] hello and welcome diabetes is a chronic progressive condition where the body has trouble maintaining a normal level of sugar in the blood over time high blood sugar can lead to different health problems there are many ways for people with diabetes to achieve and maintain healthy blood sugar levels in this video we&#39;re going to focus on management strategies so let&#39;s look at some tools in the diabetes toolbox broadly will touch on three elements blood sugar monitoring medications and healthy [Music] behaviors for many people with diabetes a key component of diabetes management is keeping track of blood sugar levels regular self- monitoring helps to determine how a ton of factors like food exercise and stress influence blood sugar self-monitoring can be done in a few ways with a blood sugar meter in which a blood sample is taken from a fingerprick and test it manually on a small device or with a wearable continuous blood sugar monitor which is worn as a sensor under the skin determining the glucose monitoring system that is right for you is about finding the option that best suits your needs talk to your healthcare provider about the different systems that are available to you how often you should be testing and when it&#39;s also important to discuss with your provider what the numbers mean and how you can use the information obtained from your monitoring to guide your diabetes IES management plan if you don&#39;t have easy access to a doctor nurse practitioner or diabetes educator you can visit your local pharmacy and ask the pharmacist for help when it comes to medications all people with type 1 diabetes will take insulin and sometimes other medications as well the insulin can be administered through an injection an insulin pump or another insulin delivery system people with type 2 diabetes often also take medications like insulin and and others these medications play different roles when it comes to managing diabetes the medications a person is prescribed are based on many things including treatment goals personal health history and medication affordability Beyond blood sugar monitoring Technologies and medications there are a host of other management strategies that can have a major impact on Diabetes including nutrition and physical activity blood sugar levels are affected in part by what a person eat needs maintaining a healthy diet is very important for people living with diabetes and pre-diabetes in general people with diabetes are incouraged to eat regular well-balanced meals limit high sugar high fat foods and opt for water as their beverage of choice incorporating vegetables and fruit whole grains and lean proteins especially plant-based ones such as beans and tofu into meals and snacks is a great foundation for a healthy diet engaging in regular physical activity is one of the most valuable things people can do for their health it is recommended that adults aim for 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise per week along with two to three sessions of resistance training such as lifting weights if this amount of exercise is a lot more than what you&#39;re used to doing start by doing less and gradually increase the amount of exercise you do over time also have fun you&#39;re more likely to stick with activity routine if you&#39;re enjoying yourself find a way to move your body that brings you Joy diabet IES is a complex condition with lots of moving Parts while the complications of the condition can be serious people with diabetes can work with their healthcare provider and take steps to manage their blood sugar and decrease risks it is possible to live a very full and healthy life with diabetes diabetes Canada is committed to improving the quality of life for all Canadians living with diabetes we work to reduce the risks associated with the condition help those affected by diabetes to live healthy lives and support research to find a cure for more information about diabetes please visit www. diabetes.com diabetes.com

Diabetes is a condition where your blood glucose 
level also known as blood sugar level is too high.   There are two main types of diabetes: Type 1 
and Type 2. There are also some rarer types   but they&#39;re all serious and can be diagnosed 
by your GP. The signs and symptoms you need to   look out for are: weeing often, because your body 
will be trying to lower your blood sugar levels   by flushing out the extra sugar in your blood. 
This can lead to other symptoms including   feeling really thirsty or genital itching and 
thrush. This can happen if your wee contains a   lot of sugar from your blood because it can 
create an environment for fungal infections.   You may also feel tired because the sugar 
in your blood can&#39;t get into your cells to   turn into energy this could lead to your body 
trying to break down its fat stores instead. So you might find that you are losing 
weight without really trying to. Wounds might also take longer to heal because high 
blood sugar levels can limit nutrients and oxygen   from getting to your wound. And your eyesight might 
be blurry as blood sugar can build up making it   harder to see. With type 1 diabetes, the symptoms 
can be more obvious and develop much quicker.   Over a few days or weeks. With type 2 diabetes, the 
symptoms can develop much slower and some people   may not have any symptoms. This is why 
some people can live with type 2 for years   without realizing they have it. If you do notice 
any of the symptoms contact your GP straight away.   Getting diagnosed can be the 
first step to getting treatment   and support so that you can find ways to 
live well with diabetes as soon as possible.

type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes are conditions that affect millions of people they can lead to heart disease and stroke which are the first and third leading causes of death and disability in the united states respectively people with diabetes and pre-diabetes can develop problems with their vision and lose feeling in their limbs they may develop liver and kidney disease and are at risk for stroke and heart attack however type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes can be avoided and risk can be reversed what is diabetes diabetes is a complex disease that affects many parts of your body but is caused by the way your body mishandles the food you eat after a meal food is broken down into sugar molecules called glucose glucose travels through the intestines into the blood where it is carried to all different areas of the body and is used for energy there are some parts of your body that need help absorbing the glucose molecules and require a special hormone called insulin insulin is formed in the pancreas and circulates in the blood with glucose to the cells that need help specifically liver cells fat cells and muscle cells when the body develops resistance to insulin increasing amounts of insulin are necessary for it to be able to utilize glucose initially during insulin resistance your pancreas will work on overtime to produce more insulin this can happen even when your glucose levels are relatively normal if tests reveal abnormally high insulin levels a condition called hyperinsulinemia along with insulin resistance markers your body shows initial risk for developing diabetes lots of insulin in the blood also affects the production of lipids and lipoproteins which are the small particles that are broken down from cholesterol molecules and fat products called triglycerides these particles are small enough to travel in your bloodstream but can be dangerous in large amounts when they build up in your blood vessels in the presence of elevated levels of insulin your body especially your liver releases bad cholesterol particles such as vldl and the higher your insulin levels the more bad cholesterol particles are circulating in your bloodstream a condition called dyslipidemia furthermore adiponectin a hormone released by your fat cells that helps break down lipids in particular free fatty acids is often low in obese or insulin resistant patients prior to developing type 2 diabetes while such lipid and lipoprotein markers are traditionally tested to measure cholesterol they also provide insightful clues on the extent of insulin resistance after a while the pancreas will become overworked and the special beta cells that produce insulin will begin to die some tests will measure how well your beta cells function and if they are showing strain beta cell dysfunction means that your body can no longer make enough insulin to help your cells take up glucose for energy and high levels of glucose will remain in your blood a condition called hyperglycemia when insulin levels are low your body may react in a number of ways some of the cells that use insulin to control glucose levels have the ability to store glucose liver and muscle cells will begin to release stored glucose when insulin levels are low in order to provide the body energy without adequate levels of insulin in the presence of insulin resistance more and more glucose is released into the bloodstream and the effects of hyperglycemia are heightened markers of glycemic control are usually measured during periods of fasting when your blood sugar should be low test results that demonstrate consistently high glucose levels are the defining characteristic of pre-diabetes and diabetes to summarize how diabetes develops let&#39;s review the main features high insulin levels mark the beginning of insulin resistance the primary mechanism that leads to pre-diabetes and diabetes abnormal levels of lipids lipoproteins and the hormone adiponectin may further indicate insulin resistance a drop in insulin production by the pancreas occurs from strain on the hormone-producing beta cells and beta cell dysfunction eventually leads to an insulin deficiency without adequate levels of insulin your body&#39;s ability to control glucose levels is disrupted and glucose levels increase defining the onset of prediabetes and diabetes too much glucose circulating in your blood hyperglycemia and too many harmful lipids circulating in your blood dyslipidemia are two conditions that are characteristic of prediabetes and diabetes left untreated they cause serious damage to the blood vessels leading to a variety of complications excess levels of lipids and lipoprotein particles can build up to create a plaque in your blood vessels this is heightened in the presence of excess glucose molecules and free fatty acids due to blockage in your vessels blood cannot circulate to your limbs and the nutrients and oxygen carried by your blood cannot nourish your body&#39;s extremities build up causes the vessels to expand and squeeze the nerves that course alongside them leading to a condition called neuropathy damaged nerves can cause numbness and keep you from healing normally they can cause your muscles to weaken and eventually atrophy sometimes requiring amputation and you may experience sensory changes including blindness involuntary functions such as blood pressure and heart rate and even sexual function may become abnormal as a symptom of neuropathy in large vessels like those supplying your heart and your brain plaque buildup leads to a condition called atherosclerosis over time the plaque can grow and rupture which can cause cardiovascular disease or a heart attack or in the brain can lead to a stroke atherosclerosis further contributes to end-organ damage like kidney or liver disease [Music] you

scientists have now basically cured type 1 diabetes what in a stunning world first researchers have been able to take the cells out of a 25-year-old patient and then make them into a plur potent State once into this reprogrammable cell State the cells were able to differentiate again into the kinds of cells that her body really needed to help produce the insulin that she couldn&#39;t on her own the researchers then injected these cells back into her abdomen and within 3 months she was producing enough insulin that she didn&#39;t need insulin topups anymore now this isn&#39;t exactly a cure that&#39;s going to work for everyone in the short term a lot more research and testing has to be done outside researchers have said they want to see this woman continue to produce her own insulin for up to 5 years but if this works it&#39;s going to be a huge sigh of relief for millions of people with type 1 diabetes around the world that&#39;s science baby

it may even go unnoticed while in case of type 1 diabetes the symptoms usually occur early and are much more severe than type 2 let&#39;s now take a look at the early signs of diabetes first one hunger and fatigue the food that we eat is converted into glucose and this glucose is utilized by our cells for energy but our cells need insulin to take in glucose and if the body doesn&#39;t make enough or any insulin or if the cells are resistant to insulin then this glucose can&#39;t get into them and you have no energy this can make you even more hungrier and more tired than usual second sign is peeing more often and being thirstier a person with diabetes may need to pee a lot more than an average person normally your body reabsorbs glucose as it passes through the kidney but when the blood sugar goes up as in the case of diabetes the kidneys may not be able to bring it all back in and this causes the body to make more urine and this takes more fluid so this will make you very thirsty and you will drink more water so when you drink more water you will also pee more third is dry mouth and itchy skin because the body is using a lot of fluid to make urine there&#39;s less moisture available for other things and this can make you dehydrated and your mouth may feel dry and dry skin can make you itchy fourth is blurred vision the changing fluid levels in the body can make the lens in the eye swell up and since the lenses change shape and can&#39;t focus properly our vision is blurred let&#39;s now take a look at the symptoms of diabetes the symptoms appear after the can you drink alcohol if you have diabetes being diabetic and drinking alcohol can be a tricky situation you might want to know whether it&#39;s safe to drink alcohol during diabetes and how much is okay to drink well you can still drink alcohol even if you have diabetes however it is very important to be aware of the effects that alcohol has on your body one alcohol even in small amount may cause blood sugar to rise this is because alcohol such as beer and wine has carbohydrates and sugar in them second consuming excess alcohol can actually decrease your blood sugar level sometimes even causing it to drop into dangerous levels moreover there are other health risks around drinking drinking excessively may lead to risk of getting cancer heart disease high blood pressure and even liver disease so while there is not a definite no it is important to remember if you have diabetes you should limit your intake of alcohol

Can you
have oatmeal when you have diabetes? That’s a really good question because
no matter how healthy oats actually are, in some cases, you may still notice
that they spike your blood sugar levels. But why? I’ll talk about all of that in this video,
so let’s get into it! So, one of the main reasons why it can be
a little hard to wrap your head around whether oatmeal is good for people
with diabetes is that it’s a carbohydrate. But don’t get tricked:
it can be a great addition to your diet while managing diabetes,
especially if you eat them for breakfast instead of high-carb, high-sugar meals,
such as white bread or other pastries. Oats have a glycemic
index score of 55 or lower when prepared with minimal processing,
which makes them less likely to cause spikes in blood sugar levels. Half a cup of oats
contains 52 grams of carbs, and I know that you may not like
what you hear here since it’s a lot. However, it is important to consider
that about 8 of these grams come in the form of fiber. And fiber has been shown
to have significant blood-sugar-reducing properties. Keep in mind that The American Diabetes
Association notes that adults should eat at least 25–30 grams of fiber each day, but most people don’t even come close. And a serving of oatmeal adds
8 grams of fiber to the diet, making it much easier
to reach dietary recommendations. Fiber-rich foods like oatmeal
may also help keep you feeling satisfied for longer. But with that in mind,
it is still important to eat oats in moderation and follow a meal plan
that is suitable for diabetes. However, oatmeal can be made of different
types of oats, and when it comes to blood sugar management,
they are not all created equal. It’s really important
what kind of oatmeals you choose. The best options are old-fashioned
or steel-cut oats. They contain a higher amount of soluble
fiber that slows digestion and helps better
regulate blood sugar. Oatmeal in its most basic
form is simply oats and water,
but I know it may taste really bland. The good news is that there are a few safe
ways to add flavor to simple oatmeal
and make it more enjoyable. So here’s what you can do:
Add some cinnamon. Use low-fat milk. Mix it with the water during cooking
or add it at the end. This gives the oatmeal a richer flavor. Add a tablespoon of nut butter for extra protein and flavor.
Add berries. They have antioxidants, good nutrients,
and can act as a natural sweetener.
Alright, so keep in mind that as long as you keep your total carbs
or GI scores in mind, there are loads of ways
to make basic oatmeal outstanding. But do you remember I talked about those
blood sugar spikes after eating oatmeal? Well, there’s a chance that it happens
because you choose the wrong type of oats. What you really need to avoid is processed
oats, instant oats, and cereal bars. These are highly processed,
which means they are digested faster, and the blood sugar increases faster
as well. Also, instant oatmeal often
has added sugar and other ingredients, so it’s a great possibility that you’ll
consume too much of them at one time. Okay, I want you to listen
carefully now: there’s no such thing as a single best “diabetes
diet.” There isn’t ONE food that works for everyone. And we can also apply it to oatmeal. Oatmeal has a lot of great health
benefits, and studies have shown that it can be beneficial for people
with diabetes. But we’re all different,
and how your blood sugars react to eating oatmeal might be different from how other
people&#39;s blood sugars react. So it’s important that you learn
what works for you. Measure your blood sugars before
and after your oatmeal. This way, you’ll understand
how it affects your blood sugar. Once you’ve done that a few times,
you can make an informed decision on whether oatmeal is the right choice
for your daily breakfast or just something to be enjoyed
occasionally. Now watch these videos that you can see right
here, stay safe, and see you next time!

research shows the best chance you have of putting type 2 diabetes into remission is to lose weight this will significantly improve your health now and for the future why because there&#39;s a link between Type 2 diabetes and having a buildup of fat inside your body regardless of your weight or size we all have different levels of fat in and around our organs this internal fat is like traffic on a road a small amount of fat inside your organs is normal just like a steady flow of traffic is normal on a road but when fat builds up it causes congestion and like too much traffic on the road too much fat around organs can slow things down stopping them from working well the liver and pancreas are vital organs that control blood sugar levels your blood sugars rise when they don&#39;t work properly losing weight and keeping it off can reduce the buildup of fat inside the liver and pancreas helping them to work as they should if they start doing their job well enough again they can bring your blood sugar levels below the diabetes range and keep them there longterm without the need for blood sugar lowering medications this can be life changing weight loss for emission is very individual and may be easier for some than others but any weight you lose trying for a mission can have huge benefits including reducing your risk of heart attacks and strokes taking fewer medications and feeling better dayto day for more information and support including options for trying remission safely explore our website and speak to your Healthcare [Music] team

hi I&#39;m Lisa Valente and today we&#39;re sharing diabetes friendly tips for going to the grocery store if you or a loved one has been recently diagnosed with diabetes you may be figuring out a lot of new steps as you learn to manage your diabetes adjusting your diet is a key part and if it&#39;s feeling overwhelming hopefully we can help simplify it today we&#39;ll talk about foods to eat more of foods to limit tips for the grocery store and tips for dining out when you have diabetes foods to enjoy diabetes diet guidelines are actually pretty similar to General healthy eating guidelines you want to balance your meals with lean proteins non-starchy vegetables complex carbohydrates and healthy fats protein Rich options include chicken seafood beef pork tofu and eggs non-star vegetables are dark leafy greens Peppers asparagus cabbage cauliflower broccoli onions mushrooms celery complex carbohydrates deliver fiber so think of whole grains like oats whole wheat bread quinoa starchy vegetables like corn potatoes and squash fruit and beans healthy fats include avocados nuts seeds and olive oil one key difference is that when you have diabetes you need to be much more mindful of the amount of carbohydrates in your diet that includes carbs coming from grains and starches like rice noodles and bread as well as fruit milk drinks and desserts some people with diabetes prefer a lower carb diet while some eat more moderate carbohydrates and research has shown that you can manage your diabetes with either style of eating it is is a myth that you have to cut out all carbs when you have diabetes find a level that works for you with your Healthcare team and adjust as needed now let&#39;s talk about foods to limit while no foods are strictly off limits there are some you should enjoy more sparingly sugary drinks sodas sweet teas and other sugar sweetened beverages can quickly raise blood sugar levels even though fruit juice doesn&#39;t contain added sugar it&#39;s still best to choose whole fruits instead because they have fiber traditional desserts things like ice cream brownies cakes cookies candy these contain a fair amount of carbohydrates mostly coming from refined grains and added sugar without a lot of nutrients you can still have them but be mindful of portion size and look for recipes that may have more diabetes friendly Alternatives like almond flour or non-nutritive sweeteners high carb foods white bread pasta and rice these are not off limits but opt for whole grain Alternatives when you can and be sure to pair smaller amounts of these carbridge foods with protein and veggies other foods and nutrients you may want to limit include Ultra processed foods saturated fat and sodium alcohol alcohol is not a drink that&#39;s recommended for health reasons for anyone but when you have diabetes alcohol can impact your blood sugar negatively here are some grocery shopping tips it&#39;s helpful to know which foods to focus on and limit but how do you shop for food let&#39;s talk through some shopping advice so navigating the grocery store doesn&#39;t feel so tricky plan ahead having an idea of what you&#39;re going to make and cook sets you up for healthy eating success make a grocery list to minimize impulsive purchases and stock up on Diabetes Friendly Foods this helps save you money and get more healthy options into your home Choose Wisely sometimes two products that are very similar say to salad dressings or two yogurts are actually very different when it comes to their nutrition one might have twice as much added sugar as the next so compare labels for processed foods to pick the best option for you it&#39;s not always about carbs it may be that one has more fiber and protein and is more satisfying or one has less sodium it&#39;s always a good idea to check labels and compare do this when you&#39;re buying items like sauces crackers breads yogurts jams and more shop for Staples in a dream world everyone would have a meal plan and know what&#39;s for dinner but sometimes we&#39;re eating on the Fly that&#39;s when having some healthy Staples on hand can be really helpful maybe you always have plain yogurt for a snack or easy breakfast eggs are great for breakfast lunch or dinner you can keep whole wheat or low carb bread in your freezer for toast beans canant tuna Frozen fruits and frozen vegetables without added sauces are also great to have on hand having some healthy options on hand will help guide you to easy meals and snacks when you&#39;re not quite sure what to make understanding food labels is key to making informed choices here&#39;s what to look for serving size all nutrition information is based on the serving size so be mindful of how much you consume serving size doesn&#39;t mean that that&#39;s how much you have to eat or drink you might have more or less but all the nutrition information is tied to the serving size amount listed total carbohydrates this number includes sugars starches and fiber aim for foods with lower total carbs fiber high fiber foods help slow down carbohydrate absorption and keep you feeling full for longer added sugars limit foods with high added sugars which can quickly raise blood sugar levels without a lot of nutrition protein foods that contain protein also help fill you up saturated fat try to keep this to less than 10% of your total calories sodium be especially mindful of sodium if you have high blood pressure or told by your doctor to limit your sodium intake vitamins and minerals not all vitamins and minerals are listed on the label but some key ones are macronutrients that&#39;s carbs protein and fat are important for blood sugar balance and satiety but getting enough micronutrients vitamins and minerals is key for your health as well then there&#39;s the ingredient list there&#39;s no hard and fast rules when it comes to ingredients many people advise to look for foods that are as close to homemade as possible and with ingredients you can pronounce I don&#39;t think that&#39;s a bad idea and it can be a good way to cut back on Ultra processed foods but I tend to be more concerned with the ingredients themselves as far as the amount of added sugar and the type of carbohydrates included understanding some food label Basics can help you make better and more informed choices when it comes to eating out having diabetes doesn&#39;t mean that you can&#39;t go to a restaurant but keep these strategies in mind preview the menu many restaurants post menus online allowing you to plan a diabetes friendly Choice make substitutions don&#39;t be afraid to ask for steamed vegetables instead of fries or a side salad instead of bread it&#39;s not that you can never have fries or bread but I probably skip having both in the same meal and cutting down on the amount that you do have and watch your portion size in general restaurant portions can be really large so consider sharing or taking half home it may feel tricky at first like you have to spend hours at the grocery store or give up all your favorite foods if you have diabetes but it will get easier adapting to a diabetes friendly diet takes time and practice if you aren&#39;t quite ready to overhaul everything you eat start small and make a few changes and then once you get the hang of those make a few more monitor your carb intake focus on Whole Foods read food labels and don&#39;t be afraid to make smart swaps and substitutions we have more resources on healthline.com to help you navigate your diabetes Journey let us know what questions you have about healthy eating when you have diabetes in the comments down below and don&#39;t forget to like subscribe and hit that Bell for more from me and Heine

sugar you&#39;re also naturally going to retain sodium and so if your body is going to hold this salt it&#39;s also going to need more water and so you have this feedback loop where you&#39;re five tips for Diabetic Care number one get annual diabetic eye exam to monitor for diabetic eye complication number two get annual flot exam in case you have any diabetic ulcer wounds because wound doesn&#39;t heal as quickly in diabetic patient number three always keep some glucose tablets or snack with you especially if you&#39;re on insulin to prevent hypoglycemia number four keep a well balanced diet which mean one portion of starch one p por of protein and two portions of vegetables lastly number five rotate insulin injection site to prevent scar tissue

does red Meek cause diabetes Well two major studies were published this week in natural metabolism and the Lancet arguing for a link between red meat intake and diabetes as expected the media has jumped all over it claiming that red meat causes diabetes but when we take a closer look at these studies what do we see these studies boast tiny effect sizes in the case of the metaanalysis massive group heterogeneity and substantial confounders like higher consumption of Western diets more obesity more smoking and while there are statistical adjustments one can try to do you can never adjust away confidently all of these factors so when you combine these things including tiny effect sizes large group heterogen significant confounders what you&#39;re left with is basically a statistical quirk

As of 2019, over 37 million
Americans, or 11.3% of the population had diabetes. I&#39;ve had type one diabetes
for 25 years, and the best thing a diabetic can do to
stay healthy is to keep their blood sugars in
normal range. Technology like continuous
glucose monitors or cgms allow diabetics to see
their blood sugar 24/7 Cgms are incredibly useful
tools, allowing diabetics to get insight on how blood
sugar reacts to insulin, food and many other things
that affect it. Abbott Laboratories focuses
on diagnostics, pharmaceuticals and medical
devices. There are a few companies
who make Cgms, but Abbott and Dexcom are the leaders
in the space. In 2021, Freestyle Libre
sales totaled $3.7 billion, with 4 million users
globally, while Dexcom, who only makes CGM Systems,
reported $2.4 billion in revenue in 2021 and 1.25
million users globally. Abbott&#39;s previously based
systems were flash cgms, meaning you had to hold
your reader or phone up to the sensor to get a
reading, a tool more suitable for diabetics who
may not need to check blood sugar readings quite as
often. Abbott&#39;s newest CGM, the
Freestyle Libre three, has just been released. It&#39;s now sending data
straight to your phone. Abbott sent CNBC three
sensors to review. Let&#39;s check it out. The cartridge comes in a
small box and is rather compact. The Libre three is
FDA approved to only be used in the arm. Okay, Ready? Three, two, one. And there she is. It&#39;s so small. Open the app and scan the
sensor. Then it takes 60 minutes to
warm up during the first 12 hours. A blood drop icon
will appear. Abbott says the sensor is
acclimating in that time and to use a glucometer to
ensure that the sensor is accurate. I found that it
was accurate as soon as I put it on. It still doesn&#39;t
require finger sticks or calibration. The system
stays on for 14 days. It gives a new reading
every minute versus every 5 minutes. Like the Dexcom
G6, The adhesive worked well and showed no sign of
falling off after 14 days. The trend arrows tell you
if your glucose is steady, rising or falling, the
alarms are customizable. You have the option to
silence low and high alerts. The urgent low alarm cannot
be silenced, which is an FDA requirement. The app does
have some good features with graphs for your average
glucose, time and range and a share option for loved
ones. It also has a reports
feature that gives you insights into patterns
allowing you to make dosage adjustments. I put my
Dexcom G6 nearby to compare the sizes and there is a
big difference. After using the library for
over a month, I had a few key takeaways and the
biggest one is just how small it is. I kept
forgetting that I even had it on. The library was
accurate most of the time. I found that during times
of rapid change, like if I forgot to take insulin for
a meal, it became inaccurate and had a hard time keeping
up. There were a few things
that I think could be improved in the app. You can&#39;t customize the
graph size. I&#39;d like the ability to
choose that, so it&#39;s a little bit tighter. You
also can&#39;t zoom in to past readings. Sometimes when
I&#39;m having a low blood sugar, I like to be able to
zoom in and see how quickly the number is changing. And while it does send
notifications to my iWatch, they have yet to make an
app compatible to use with it. So seeing your blood
sugar value on your watch is not possible yet. Abbott says that&#39;s
something they are working on for the future. The Libre three is
prescription only, so the cost will be different for
everyone. Abbott said users with
insurance can expect to pay 0 to $25 per sensor and $70
per sensor without insurance. So would I
recommend this to other diabetics? Yes, but it
depends on the user. For diabetics like me who
use an insulin pump, the LIBRE three still isn&#39;t
compatible with them yet, although Abbott says they
should be in the near future for diabetics who use
multiple daily injections or diet to manage their
diabetes. I think the Libre three is a great tool to
help manage blood sugar.

step one wash the bitter gourds thoroughly under running water step two cut the bitter gourds in half lengthwise step three scoop out the seeds and the white flesh around them step four slice the cleaned bitter gourd into smaller pieces step five add the chopped pieces into the blender along with a little water blend until smooth step six pour the mixture through a strainer while gently pressing on the solids with a spoon to get as much juice out as possible step seven add a squeeze of lemon juice to improve the taste step eight serve the juice chilled

can you drink alcohol if you have diabetes being diabetic and drinking alcohol can be a tricky situation you might want to know whether it&#39;s safe to drink alcohol during diabetes and how much is okay to drink well you can still drink alcohol even if you have diabetes however it is very important to be aware of the effects that alcohol has on your body one alcohol even in small amount may cause blood sugar to rise this is because alcohol such as beer and wine has carbohydrates and sugar in them second consuming excess alcohol can actually decrease your blood sugar level sometimes even causing it to drop into dangerous levels moreover there are other health risks around drinking drinking excessively may lead to risk of getting cancer heart disease high blood pressure and even liver disease so while there is not a definite no it is important to remember if you have diabetes you should limit your intake of alcohol

type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes are conditions that affect millions of people they can lead to heart disease and stroke which are the first and third leading causes of death and disability in the united states respectively people with diabetes and pre-diabetes can develop problems with their vision and lose feeling in their limbs they may develop liver and kidney disease and are at risk for stroke and heart attack however type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes can be avoided and risk can be reversed what is diabetes diabetes is a complex disease that affects many parts of your body but is caused by the way your body mishandles the food you eat after a meal food is broken down into sugar molecules called glucose glucose travels through the intestines into the blood where it is carried to all different areas of the body and is used for energy there are some parts of your body that need help absorbing the glucose molecules and require a special hormone called insulin insulin is formed in the pancreas and circulates in the blood with glucose to the cells that need help specifically liver cells fat cells and muscle cells when the body develops resistance to insulin increasing amounts of insulin are necessary for it to be able to utilize glucose initially during insulin resistance your pancreas will work on overtime to produce more insulin this can happen even when your glucose levels are relatively normal if tests reveal abnormally high insulin levels a condition called hyperinsulinemia along with insulin resistance markers your body shows initial risk for developing diabetes lots of insulin in the blood also affects the production of lipids and lipoproteins which are the small particles that are broken down from cholesterol molecules and fat products called triglycerides these particles are small enough to travel in your bloodstream but can be dangerous in large amounts when they build up in your blood vessels in the presence of elevated levels of insulin your body especially your liver releases bad cholesterol particles such as vldl and the higher your insulin levels the more bad cholesterol particles are circulating in your bloodstream a condition called dyslipidemia furthermore adiponectin a hormone released by your fat cells that helps break down lipids in particular free fatty acids is often low in obese or insulin resistant patients prior to developing type 2 diabetes while such lipid and lipoprotein markers are traditionally tested to measure cholesterol they also provide insightful clues on the extent of insulin resistance after a while the pancreas will become overworked and the special beta cells that produce insulin will begin to die some tests will measure how well your beta cells function and if they are showing strain beta cell dysfunction means that your body can no longer make enough insulin to help your cells take up glucose for energy and high levels of glucose will remain in your blood a condition called hyperglycemia when insulin levels are low your body may react in a number of ways some of the cells that use insulin to control glucose levels have the ability to store glucose liver and muscle cells will begin to release stored glucose when insulin levels are low in order to provide the body energy without adequate levels of insulin in the presence of insulin resistance more and more glucose is released into the bloodstream and the effects of hyperglycemia are heightened markers of glycemic control are usually measured during periods of fasting when your blood sugar should be low test results that demonstrate consistently high glucose levels are the defining characteristic of pre-diabetes and diabetes to summarize how diabetes develops let&#39;s review the main features high insulin levels mark the beginning of insulin resistance the primary mechanism that leads to pre-diabetes and diabetes abnormal levels of lipids lipoproteins and the hormone adiponectin may further indicate insulin resistance a drop in insulin production by the pancreas occurs from strain on the hormone-producing beta cells and beta cell dysfunction eventually leads to an insulin deficiency without adequate levels of insulin your body&#39;s ability to control glucose levels is disrupted and glucose levels increase defining the onset of prediabetes and diabetes too much glucose circulating in your blood hyperglycemia and too many harmful lipids circulating in your blood dyslipidemia are two conditions that are characteristic of prediabetes and diabetes left untreated they cause serious damage to the blood vessels leading to a variety of complications excess levels of lipids and lipoprotein particles can build up to create a plaque in your blood vessels this is heightened in the presence of excess glucose molecules and free fatty acids due to blockage in your vessels blood cannot circulate to your limbs and the nutrients and oxygen carried by your blood cannot nourish your body&#39;s extremities build up causes the vessels to expand and squeeze the nerves that course alongside them leading to a condition called neuropathy damaged nerves can cause numbness and keep you from healing normally they can cause your muscles to weaken and eventually atrophy sometimes requiring amputation and you may experience sensory changes including blindness involuntary functions such as blood pressure and heart rate and even sexual function may become abnormal as a symptom of neuropathy in large vessels like those supplying your heart and your brain plaque buildup leads to a condition called atherosclerosis over time the plaque can grow and rupture which can cause cardiovascular disease or a heart attack or in the brain can lead to a stroke atherosclerosis further contributes to end-organ damage like kidney or liver disease [Music] you

here are six symptoms that could indicate diabetes feeling very thirsty peeing more frequently than usual particularly at night feeling very tired weight loss and loss of muscle bulk itching around the penis or vagina or frequent episodes of thrush and finally blurred vision now once these can be caused by other conditions it&#39;s worth seeing your doctor if you have any of them to find out what the underlying cause could be

one of the endocrine functions of the pancreas is 
to secrete a hormone called insulin into the blood   microscopic regions of beta cells in the pancreas 
are located on the eyelets of longerons these beta   cells release insulin after consumption 
of a meal increasing amounts of glucose   in the blood trigger beta cells in the eyelets to 
secrete the appropriate amount of insulin hormone   which travels through the bloodstream to target 
cells where it promotes the transport of glucose   into the cells glucose must get inside cells to 
participate in cellular respiration which creates   the energy needed for cellular processes certain 
tissues such as skeletal muscle and adapost tissue   require insulin to unlock their cells before 
glucose can enter insulin attaches to specific   receptors on the cell&#39;s surface causing glucose 
transporter proteins in the the cell membrane to   open allowing glucose to pass into the cell as 
cells take up glucose the blood glucose level   Falls type 1 diabetes is a disease in which the 
pancreas loses its ability to produce insulin   resulting in high blood glucose levels and other 
metabolic complications in this disease antibodies   secreted by lymphocytes attack and destroy the 
beta cells so the pancreas produces little or   no insulin lack of sufficient insulin prevents 
glucose from entering cells resulting in a high   blood glucose concentration a condition called 
hypoglycemia unable to pass into cells glucose   builds up in the blood the kidneys filter out the 
excess glucose which is lost in urine resulting   in glycosuria or large quantities of glucose in 
the urine common symptoms of hyperglycemia in   type 1 diabetes include polyphasia or excessive 
eating polydipsia or excessive thirst polyuria   or increased urine volume and unexplained weight 
loss as the insulin deficiency continues cells   are unable to use sugar for energy so the 
body breaks down fats and proteins to use   them as an alternative source of energy as fat 
breakdown continues acidic byproducts known as   Ketone bodies accumulate in the blood result in a 
condition called ketosis if allowed to build up to   Dangerously high levels a life-threatening 
condition called diabetic keto acidosis results type 1 diabetes can cause degenerative   tissue damage resulting in 
long-term complications such as atherosclerosis blindness neuropathy and renal dysfunction licensed health professionals 
prescribe insulin replacement therapy to   treat type 1 diabetes if a diabetic person 
uses a syringe to deliver doses of insulin   he or she must rotate between injection sites to 
prevent localized tissue damage and absorption   problems once delivered via syringe or insulin 
pump the insulin rapidly reduces hypoglycemia   facilitating transport of glucose into cells 
insulin also suppresses ketosis restoring   metabolic balance in addition to insulin therapy 
patients must manage their glucose levels closely   with frequent glucose checks which should 
fall between 70 and 120 mg per deciliter   patients should also monitor their blood glucose 
level with periodic hemoglobin A1c tests which   measure the amount of glycated hemoglobin in the 
blood over a 2 to 3mon period glycated hemoglobin   is created when glucose attaches to hemoglobin 
within red blood cells glycated hemoglobin forms   at a rate that increases with plasma glucose 
levels the desired hemoglobin A1c level for   people with diabetes is less than 7% the higher 
the hemoglobin A1c level the higher the risk of   developing complications from diabetes other 
actions patients can take to monitor their   glucose levels more closely are diet control and 
consistent exercise by treating and controlling   blood glucose levels patients May prevent the 
occurrence of the complications of diabetes

Greetings Friends, I am Dr. Rishab Sharma In this video, we will discuss symptoms related to Diabetes And if these symptoms develop then the patient should immediately consult a good doctor and get investigations done So that this disease can be diagnosed early and the patient can get good treatment  If we talk about Type 2 Diabetes the early symptoms are very mild so the patients get to know about their Diabetic status, very late  And by the time Diabetes is diagnosed in these patients there is already, lots of damage done in their body But if we talk about Type 1 Diabetes then mostly the symptoms develop very early in Type 1 Diabetes Patient i.e. they develop within a few weeks to months But these symptoms are very severe and life-threatening in Type 1 Diabetes patients And these early symptoms of Diabetes are mostly due to raised blood sugar levels So let&#39;s start this discussion about symptoms of Diabetes So first, there is an increase in hunger in Diabetic patients and they are tired and exhausted all the time. Because the insulin deficiency or the insulin resistance in a diabetic patient impacts the transport of glucose (energy-releasing molecule) from blood to the body cells Therefore there is decreased production of energy in the body cells And so the patient is hungry all the time or he/she is tired all the time The second common symptom is an increased frequency of urination In Diabetic patient, the normal urine frequency (which is 6-8 per day) gets increased up 14-16/day Increased frequency of urination leads to  dehydration in the patient, the patient feels dehydrated And because of this dehydration, there is an 
increase in thirst he/she feels thirsty all the time Due to this their water consumption increases And this increased water consumption in medical terms is called Polydipsia And the patient develops dry skin due to dehydration and this leads to itching and irritation on the skin Besides, the infections increase in Diabetic patients particularly the frequency of urinary tract infections and skin infections increase Besides, the patients may develop blurring of vision and, burning, numbness, tingling of hands and feet In severe cases, patient develops nausea, vomiting, and severe pain in the abdomen These were some early symptoms which develop a suspicion of Diabetes And if these symptoms develop in  a patient, he/she should get an urgent consultation with a Good Doctor and get their complete evaluation done So this completes the discussion And stay healthy and keep your blood sugar levels under control Thank You, Take Care

supplement would lower type 2 diabetes risk unfortunately it didn&#39;t the researchers detected no effect not even a little hint that isolated Coco flavanol had any impact on type 2 diabetes risk summary and conclusions what do we make of this well I&#39;d say that the data on dark chocolate and cocoa are so consistent that I would conclude that eating dark chocolate or consuming cocoa as a beverage does improve insulin sensitivity in people who are insulin resistant and possibly also improve beta cell function resulting in improved glucose tolerance and a lower risk of type 2 diabetes why the cosmos trial was null and did not detect any effect of isolated Coco flavanol remains unclear maybe there is more to Coco than flavanols if the cosmos trial had shown a reduction in type 2 diabetes risk with Coco flavanol supplementation the story would have been very conclusive cocoa in the form of a beverage or dark chocolate improves glucose tolerance and reduces type two diabetes risk through the action of the flavonol and cocoa now now that this trial was soundly negative showing no effect whatsoever the story is less conclusive and we remain a little unclear about what it is about dark chocolate and cocoa that exert the effect on glucose tolerance as a takeaway message I would still conclude that if you like dark chocolate or cocoa as a beverage it would seem fine to enjoy these regularly just keep in mind that eating or drinking huge amounts every day doesn&#39;t necessarily mean a bigger effect my suggestion would be to have say two to maybe four squares of dark chocolate per day with a cocoa content of at least say 80% maybe I think that dark chocolate could have a particularly positive effect on your diabetes risk and your health in general if it replaces other types of desserts or snacks higher in sugar or fat such as cookies cakes or Donuts if you prefer cocoa as a beverage that may also be a good option but keep the sugar content to a minimum now why do I recommend only two to four squares per day and not more didn&#39;t I mention that several trials used one bar of dark chocolate per day for a couple of weeks yes sure and I think in those studies a high dose was probably needed to detect an effect in a relatively short-term study for long-term potentially lifelong consumption I think there are a few other things we should consider for one it&#39;s important to consider that the sugar cocoa is often consumed with is not great in larger amounts particularly if you are concerned about blood glucose control also dark chocolate is a food with a high energy density and as I&#39;ve explained before a high energy density means that chocolate has a low satil score per calorie in other words eating too much of such a food could easily lead to an overc consumption of calories and weight gain and that is certainly not great for diabetes prevention or health in general and lastly cocoa can contain a high concentration of heavy metals such as lead and cadmium and it&#39;s very high in the an nutrient oxalate for heavy metals and also oxalates our bodies can probably manage small amounts but going overboard and having a bar of dark chocolate or more every day because you now think of chocolate as a superfood could carry some risks to me it does seem likely that enjoying a reasonable amount of say two squares and not more than around four squares per day regularly is may be a sweet spot for your enjoyment of the food with some health benefits while keeping potential risks at a minimum okay that&#39;s it for this video if being able to directly ask me questions about the videos in live calls or chat Community I&#39;ve left a link in the description box below thank you so much and take care [Music] [Music]

When you have diabetes, all fruits are the “forbidden fruits,” right? WRONG! There&#39;s no need to cut off fruits
from your diet and miss out on all the vitamins, minerals, and nutrients they
can provide, not to mention the juicy sweetness missing from the typical
diabetes-friendly diet. So let&#39;s take a look at the top 9 fruits that are the best
to eat when you have diabetes. All right, let&#39;s take a quick look at what research has to say about
fruits and diabetes. A study by the Harvard School
of Public Health revealed eating fruit was linked to up to 23% lower
risk of type 2 diabetes. Another study shows that some of the fruits have anti-obesity,
anti-inflammatory, and anti-diabetic benefits that can even lower
your “bad” LDL cholesterol. Sounds great, right? But the emphasis here
should be on “some fruits.” Eating the wrong fruit or even overeating the right fruit can rapidly
spike your blood sugar. So why does some fruit
get the green light? The short answer is fiber. The fruits I&#39;ll share today are loaded
with soluble and insoluble fiber, which as study after study shows,
prevents blood sugar fluctuations by slowing down carb
digestion and absorption of glucose. So here&#39;s the top 9 diabetes-friendly fruits that won&#39;t send you
on an insulin rollercoaster. #1: Blueberries. A real diabetes superstar, according to the American Diabetes Association. Blueberries are about 85%
water with an entire cup containing only 84 calories, 15 grams of carbs,
and 4 grams of fiber. These nutrient-dense berries are packed with vitamin C, vitamin K,
potassium, and polyphenols that give them anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, and gut-regulating abilities. Studies also link them to improved insulin resistance and a lower risk
of developing type 2 diabetes. #2: Tart Cherries. Tart cherries provide 60 calories, 15 grams of carbs, 13 grams
of sugar, and 2 grams of fiber per cup. Their dark red color comes
from anthocyanin, a compound that protects against heart disease,
cancer and other diseases. They also have nine times the vitamin A
content of blueberries, with one serving delivering 25%
of the recommended daily dose. #3: Peaches. A synonym for sweetness, you&#39;d hardly think of peaches
as a diabetes-friendly fruit. One medium sized peach provides 58 calories, 14 grams of carbs,
12 grams of sugar, and 2 grams of fiber. This one study shows that polyphenol rich peach juice combat hyperglycemia
and insulin resistance. When you&#39;re strapped for options to indulge your sweet tooth,
nothing beats a sweet and juicy peach. As long as you don&#39;t go
overboard with it, of course. #4: Apricots. It&#39;s the peaches smaller yet
still tart and sweet cousin. The apricot is known
for being rich in vitamin A, known as the &quot;good eyesight vitamin.&quot; It&#39;s also one of the safest fruits you
can eat to keep your blood sugar stable. In 2 fresh apricots,
there are 34 calories, 8 grams of carbs, 6.5 grams of sugar,
and 1.5 grams of fiber. This sweet summer jewel goes well in your
oatmeal, cereal, and seasonal fruit. #5: Apples. An apple a day keeps the blood sugar at bay. Rich in fiber and vitamin C, it&#39;s the most popular fruit in the world
for a reason: it scores a 32-38 GI, which means it doesn&#39;t instantly
spike your blood sugar. One medium apple is almost 86% water
and provides 95 calories, 25 grams of carbs, 20.6 grams
of sugar, and 4.4 grams of fiber. It really is the perfect on the go snack that can also be thrown
into any salad or cereal bowl. #6: Oranges. When it comes to diabetes, comparing
apples to oranges is a smart thing to do. A juicy, sweet orange can be a healthy part of a diabetes-friendly diet,
but monitoring your intake is key. Just one medium-sized orange has your
daily requirement of vitamin C. It also provides 62 calories, 15 grams of carbs, 12 grams of sugar,
and 3.1 grams of fiber. #7: Pears. If you ever have trouble getting enough fiber into your diet, then pears should
be your first pick of fruit to snack on. One medium pear has 5.5 grams of fiber, which is nearly 20%
of the daily recommended intake. It also contains 101 calories,
27 grams of carbs, and 21 grams of sugar. Pears, when combined with apples, have been proven to lower the risk
of type 2 diabetes by 18%. #8: Kiwi. This tropical zesty fruit is
a real vitamin C powerhouse. Kiwi is a fiber-rich superfood that helps healthy gut bacteria thrive, indirectly
helping to keep blood sugar in check. It&#39;s also rich in keratinoids,
which help protect against heart disease. One normal sized kiwi fruit has 42 calories, 10 grams of carbs,
2 grams of fiber, and 6 grams of sugar. #9: Grapefruit. I included this citrus fruit on this
list with a note of caution. One grapefruit has vitamin A, vitamin B6, potassium, and nearly an entire
day&#39;s worth of vitamin C. A medium sized grapefruit has 52 calories, 13 grams of carbs, 11 grams
of sugar, and 2 grams of fiber. While this fruit has been proven
to improve blood sugar control, it may negatively interact with some
medications, notably metformin. Consult with your doctor before
making it a daily staple. There&#39;s simply no need to see your food choices as black and white when there&#39;s
a whole rainbow of fruit you can enjoy. Before adding any of these fruits to your
meal rotation, try checking your blood sugar post-meal to see
how they affect you. Now watch another video about essential
vitamins and minerals for diabetes and the following one about foods
that help lower your blood sugar levels.
